Class CladosConstant

java.lang.Object
org.interworldtransport.cladosG.CladosConstant
public final class CladosConstant extends Object
This class just acts as a bucket for magic numbers so they aren't nightmarish to find when they change in the future.

Version:
2.0
Author:
Dr Alfred W Differ

  • Field Details

    • GENERATOR_MIN

      public static final Generator GENERATOR_MIN
      This is the smallest generator in the enumeration of the same name.

    • GENERATOR_MAX

      public static final Generator GENERATOR_MAX
      This is the largest generator in the enumeration of the same name. It's value can change here when Clados is reworked to support larger algebras. Changing it here enables all support validity testing methods to refer here instead of supporting their own 'magic numbers'.

      At present it is as large as it can be for the computer being used to test it.

    • SCALARGRADE

      public static final byte SCALARGRADE
      This is teh smallest grade supported by Clados.
      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

    • MAXGRADE

      public static final byte MAXGRADE
      This is the largest grade supported by Clados

    • MONAD_SPECIAL_CASES

      public static final List<String> MONAD_SPECIAL_CASES
      This is just a list of the special cases for Monad construction. Rather than have a copy of them in each monad class, we keep them here.

    • MINUS_ONE_F

      public static final Float MINUS_ONE_F
      Alias for -1 to help readability elsewhere. Java's Float doesn't have it.

    • MINUS_ONE_D

      public static final Double MINUS_ONE_D
      Alias for -1 to help readability elsewhere. Java's Double doesn't have it.

    • PLUS_ONE_F

      public static final Float PLUS_ONE_F
      Alias for +1 to help readability elsewhere. Java's Float doesn't have it.

      public static final Double PLUS_ONE_D
      Alias for +1 to help readability elsewhere. Java's Double doesn't have it.

  • Method Details

    • pow

      protected static final Long pow(byte base, int exponent)
      This small function is for key building and exist soley because java's Math.pow() accepts doubles and returns a double. I get why they do that, but I have fairly tight control over the inputs on this method in the Blade and Basis classes, so overflow isn't likely.

      Having said that (!), future expansion the number of generators that can be used in blades and bases will have to revisit this method since long integers have a limit... even if it is very large by current standards.

      Parameters:
      base - byte to use as the exponential base
      exponent - integer to use as the power to raise the base
      Returns:
      Long wrapped result of base^exponent
